entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog with a lovable appearance and gentle manners. Keeping it healthy is a challenge due to its many inborn physical deficiencies.

entities.name: Skin Care
entities.description: The process of maintaining the health of the English Bulldog's skin, which is layered in folds and susceptible to diseases like yeast intertrigo. This involves daily cleaning of the skin folds with a nontoxic anti-fungal wipe.

entities.name: Yeast Intertrigo
entities.description: A condition which leads to itchy rashes on the skin, common in English Bulldogs due to their skin folds.

entities.name: Skin Irritation
entities.description: A condition that may occur in English Bulldogs, characterized by constant scratching, rubbing, or biting, nasty odors, and brown discharge from skin folds.

entities.name: Veterinary Care
entities.description: Professional medical care provided by a vet, necessary when the owner cannot help the bulldog with its skin problems despite their best efforts.

entities.name: Bathing
entities.description: Bathe your dog once or twice each year. Frequent bathing could remove the natural oils which protect its skin. Use tear-free shampoo and work it into your dog’s skin folds when bathing.

entities.name: Feeding Puppy
entities.description: Young bulldogs need several small meals throughout the day, up to four times a day. Puppies generally need about 20-70 calories per pound of body weight.

entities.name: Diet Change
entities.description: Do not change your bulldog’s diet until it is at least three to four months old. After obtaining your bulldog, wait at least two weeks before changing its diet. Gradually introduce new foods into its diet and monitor your dog’s reaction.

entities.name: Feeding Adult
entities.description: The caloric needs of your bulldog will depend on its age and activity level. After about 18 months, your bulldog should be treated nutritionally as an adult. Older dogs usually need about 937 calories per day. Typical adult bulldogs need around 1,145 calories each day. A very active English bulldog could need as much as 1,300 calories in a day.

entities.name: Nutritious Diet
entities.description: Your bulldog should receive a healthy balance of protein, carbs, fats, vitamins, and minerals. Avoid dog foods that are predominately carbs like corn and sugar. Dog foods that include high protein contents and slowly-digestible carbs like sweet potatoes and barley are good choices.

entities.name: Weight Management
entities.description: If your bulldog is overweight, it may have heart, hip, and breathing problems later in life. Obesity also increases your dog’s chances of developing cancer by as much as 20%. You can keep its weight down by feeding it only moderate meals and providing opportunities for regular light exercise.

entities.name: Diet Variety
entities.description: While table scraps can often upset a bulldog’s tummy, there are many ways to include new foods and make fun changes to your dog’s meals. For instance, your bulldog might enjoy apple cinnamon drops.

entities.name: Toxic Foods
entities.description: There are many foods that humans find yummy but are toxic to bulldogs. For instance, grapes, raisins, beer, raw bread dough, chocolate or anything caffeinated, garlic, and onions should never be consumed by dogs. English bulldogs, like all dogs, should especially avoid alcohol, grapes, and raisins.

entities.name: English Bulldog's Eyes
entities.description: Many problems can develop in your dog’s eyes. Look closely at your dog’s eyes each day and monitor any unusual changes. Wipe away crusty bits or goop that often accumulates in the corners of bulldogs’ eyes. If you notice a heavy crusty layer and excessively runny eyes, take him to a vet.

entities.name: Entropion
entities.description: A condition where the dog’s eyelids are rolling inward, leading to tearing, squinting, and ulcers in the eye.

entities.name: Ectropion
entities.description: A condition where the dog’s eyelids are sagging or appear to be rolling down, leading to signs of dry eyes by blinking with unusual frequency.

entities.name: Beta-carotene
entities.description: Beta carotene strengthens the eyes. Foods high in beta-carotene are hard to find in dog food. However, adding small portions of foods high in beta carotene to your dog’s diet can keep its eyes healthy. Sweet potatoes and carrots, for instance, are good sources of beta carotene and dogs love them.

entities.name: Cherry Eye
entities.description: A common problem in English bulldogs. The red swelling is a tear gland that has prolapsed forward. It should be kept well lubricated to prevent secondary infections. While it does not usually cause pain for your dog immediately, if it gets infected, it may.

entities.description: A breed of dog that requires specific care and feeding routines.

entities.name: Adult Bulldog Feeding
entities.description: The caloric needs of a bulldog will depend on its age and activity level. After about 18 months, a bulldog should be treated nutritionally as an adult.

entities.name: Nutritious Diet
entities.description: A bulldog should receive a healthy balance of protein, carbs, fats, vitamins, and minerals.

entities.name: Healthy Weight
entities.description: Maintaining a healthy weight is important for a bulldog's health. Overweight bulldogs may have heart, hip, and breathing problems later in life.

entities.name: Diet Variety
entities.description: While table scraps can often upset a bulldog’s tummy, there are many ways to include new foods and make fun changes to your dog’s meals.

entities.name: Toxic Foods
entities.description: Certain foods that are safe for humans are toxic to bulldogs, such as grapes, raisins, beer, raw bread dough, chocolate or anything caffeinated, garlic, and onions.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog that is notoriously low-energy but requires exercise to stay healthy and engaged. They have weak respiratory systems and have difficulty breathing in hot, humid weather. They thrive off attention from their owners.

entities.name: Eye Problems
entities.description: English Bulldogs can develop many problems in their eyes such as entropion and ectropion. These conditions can lead to tearing, squinting, and ulcers in the eye.

entities.name: Cherry Eye
entities.description: A common problem in English Bulldogs where the red swelling is a tear gland that has prolapsed forward. It should be kept well lubricated to prevent secondary infections.

entities.name: Beta-carotene
entities.description: A nutrient that strengthens the eyes. Foods high in beta-carotene are hard to find in dog food. However, adding small portions of foods high in beta carotene to your dog’s diet can keep its eyes healthy.

entities.name: Neutering/Spaying
entities.description: A procedure that makes dogs less aggressive and easier to control. It also has many other positive benefits, such as lower licensing fees, reduced chance for prostrate disorders, and reduced chance for testicular cancer.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog with a lovable appearance and gentle manners. Keeping it healthy is a challenge due to its many inborn physical deficiencies.

entities.name: Skin Care
entities.description: The process of maintaining the health of the English Bulldog's skin, which includes daily cleaning of the skin folds with an anti-fungal wipe, early cleaning to prevent rashes, and making the cleaning process enjoyable for the dog.

entities.name: Skin Irritation
entities.description: A condition that may occur in English Bulldogs, characterized by constant scratching, rubbing, or biting, nasty odors, and a brown discharge from the skin folds.

entities.name: Vet
entities.description: A professional who can help with severe skin problems in English Bulldogs, such as infected, itching, and dry skin.

Older dogs usually need about 937 calories per day. Typical adult bulldogs need around 1,145 calories each day. A very active English bulldog could need as much as 1,300 calories in a day.

Dog foods that include high protein contents and slowly-digestible carbs like sweet potatoes and barley are good choices.

entities.name: Toxic Foods for Bulldogs
entities.description: There are many foods that humans find yummy but are toxic to bulldogs. For instance, grapes, raisins, beer, raw bread dough, chocolate or anything caffeinated, garlic, and onions should never be consumed by dogs.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog that is notoriously low-energy but requires exercise to stay healthy and engaged. They have weak respiratory systems and have difficulty breathing in hot, humid weather. They thrive off attention from their owners.

entities.name: Eye Problems
entities.description: English Bulldogs can develop many problems in their eyes such as entropion and ectropion. These conditions can lead to tearing, squinting, and ulcers in the eye.

entities.name: Cherry Eye
entities.description: A common problem in English Bulldogs where the red swelling is a tear gland that has prolapsed forward. It should be kept well lubricated to prevent secondary infections.

entities.name: Beta-Carotene
entities.description: A nutrient that strengthens the eyes. Foods high in beta-carotene are hard to find in dog food. However, adding small portions of foods high in beta-carotene to your dog’s diet can keep its eyes healthy.

entities.name: Exercise
entities.description: English Bulldogs require light exercise to stay healthy and engaged. This can include short walks around the block or playing around the house.

entities.name: Training
entities.description: Training an English Bulldog can be difficult and requires patience. They may not learn tricks as fast as other dogs.

entities.name: Neutering/Spaying
entities.description: Neutering or spaying your English Bulldog can make them less aggressive and easier to control. It also has many other positive benefits, such as lower licensing fees, reduced chance for prostrate disorders, and reduced chance for testicular cancer.

entities.name: Heat Stroke
entities.description: English Bulldogs are prone to heat stroke due to their flattened noses which make it more difficult for them to breathe. It is important to be cautious in hot weather.

relationships.description: English Bulldogs require regular skin care due to their skin folds which are susceptible to diseases like yeast intertrigo.
Regular skin care, specifically daily cleaning of the skin folds, can prevent yeast intertrigo in English Bulldogs.
English Bulldogs may suffer from skin irritation, characterized by constant scratching, rubbing, or biting, nasty odors, and brown discharge from skin folds.
English Bulldogs require veterinary care when the owner cannot help with its skin problems despite their best efforts.
After bathing, the next step in caring for an English Bulldog is feeding the puppy.
After feeding the puppy, the next step is to gradually change the diet as the bulldog grows.
After changing the diet, the next step is to adjust the feeding as the bulldog matures.
After adjusting the feeding, the next step is to ensure the bulldog is receiving a nutritious diet.
After ensuring a nutritious diet, the next step is to manage the bulldog's weight.
After managing the weight, the next step is to provide variety in the bulldog's diet.
After providing diet variety, it's important to avoid toxic foods.
English Bulldog's eyes can develop a condition called Entropion.
English Bulldog's eyes can develop a condition called Ectropion.
Feeding your English Bulldog foods high in Beta-carotene can keep its eyes healthy.
English Bulldog's eyes can develop a condition called Cherry Eye.

English Bulldogs require a gradual change in diet after they are three to four months old.

English Bulldogs require a balanced and nutritious diet.
English Bulldogs require maintenance of a healthy weight to avoid health issues.
English Bulldogs can have a variety in their diet, but certain foods can upset their stomach.
English Bulldogs should avoid certain foods that are toxic to them.
English Bulldogs are prone to developing many problems in their eyes such as entropion and ectropion.
Cherry eye is a common problem in English Bulldogs.
Beta carotene strengthens the eyes and can help prevent eye problems in English Bulldogs.
Neutering or spaying an English Bulldog makes them less aggressive and easier to control.
English Bulldogs require regular skin care to maintain their health due to their inborn physical deficiencies.
Proper skin care can prevent skin irritation in English Bulldogs.
If skin irritation in an English Bulldog cannot be managed despite best efforts, consultation with a vet is required.
